BGR, 6 Jan 2016</ref> - Initially however was estimated at {{convert|40|ktonTNT|TJ}}<ref name=BGR2013>[http://www.bgr.bund.de/DE/Gemeinsames/Oeffentlichkeitsarbeit/Pressemitteilungen/BGR/bgr-130212_Kernwaffentest-Nordkorea.html Nordkorea: BGR registriert vermutlichen Kernwaffentest] - BGR (In German), 12 Feb 2013</ref> |previous_test =[[2009 North Korean nuclear test|2009 test]] |next_test =[[January 2016 North Korean nuclear test|January 2016 test]] }} {{DPRK WMD}} On 12 February 2013, [[North Korea]]n state media announced it had conducted an [[Underground nuclear testing|underground nuclear test]], its third in seven years. A tremor that exhibited a nuclear bomb signature with an initial [[Moment magnitude scale|magnitude]] 4.9 (later revised to 5.1) was detected by the [[China Earthquake Networks Center]],<ref name="朝鲜疑爆Ms4.9地震">{{cite web|title=朝鲜(疑爆)Ms4.9地震 |url=http://www.csndmc.ac.cn/newweb/secondpage.jsp?id=1146 |language=Chinese |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140809151257/http://www.csndmc.ac.cn/newweb/secondpage.jsp?id=1146 |archivedate=9 August 2014 }}</ref> [[Preparatory Commission for the Comprehensive Nuclear-Test-Ban Treaty Organization]]<ref>{{cite web|title=Press Release: On the CTBTO's detection in North Korea|url=http://www.ctbto.org/press-centre/press-releases/2013/on-the-ctbtos-detection-in-north-korea/|publisher=CTBTO|accessdate=12 February 2013}}</ref> and the [[United States Geological Survey]].<ref name="USGS report 2013 nuclear test"/> In response, [[Japan]] summoned an emergency [[United Nations]] meeting for 12 February and [[South Korea]] raised its military alert status. It is not known whether the explosion was nuclear or a conventional explosion designed to mimic a nuclear blast;<ref>Broad, William, "[http://www.nytimes.com/2013/02/13/world/asia/despite-claims-of-third-blast-north-korean-nuclear-program-remains-a-mystery.html?src=recg A Secretive Country Gives Experts Few Clues to Judge Its Nuclear Program]", ''New York Times'', 12 February 2013. "As is usual with tests by the secretive North, it was not even clear if the underground test was nuclear, rather than conventional bomb blasts meant to mimic an underground nuclear test;"</ref> as of two days after the blast, Chinese, Japanese, and South Korean investigators had failed to detect any radiation.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-21455080 |title=BBC News - North Korea nuclear test: No radiation detected |publisher=bbc.co.uk |date=2013-02-14 |accessdate=2013-04-16}}</ref>
== Test == [[File:North Korea nuclear test 2013.jpg|thumbnail|left|USGS infographic on the event]]
On 12 February 2013, a spokesman for North Korea's army command said it had successfully conducted a third underground [[Nuclear weapons testing|nuclear weapons test]], according to the [[Yonhap]].<ref>{{cite web |title=(URGENT) N. Korea confirms it conducted third nuclear test |url=http://english.yonhapnews.co.kr/news/2013/02/12/0200000000AEN20130212010000315.HTML |publisher=YonHapNews |date=12 February 2013 |accessdate=12 February 2013}}</ref><ref name="Nuke">{{cite web |url=http://www.koreanconfidential.com/dprknukethreatmarch13.html |title=North Korea Nuclear Threat |date=5 March 2013 |accessdate=26 March 2013}}</ref> North Korea also said the test had used a miniaturized nuclear device with greater explosive power.<ref>{{cite news|title=N.Korea says test used miniaturised nuclear device with greater explosive force |url=http://english.ruvr.ru/2013_02_12/N-Korea-says-test-used-miniaturised-nuclear-device-with-greater-explosive-force-KCNA/ |publisher=Voice of Russia|date=12 February 2013|accessdate=12 February 2013}}</ref>
Before North Korea announced they had conducted the test, [[seismic activity]] had already been detected in [[North Korea]] by the United States Geological Survey (USGS) and the seismic network operated by the Comprehensive Nuclear-Test-Ban Treaty Organization (CTBTO) Preparatory Commission, near the site of previous nuclear tests at [[Mantapsan]] in [[Kilju County]]. A large tremor, first estimated at magnitude of 4.9, was detected in North Korea, and governments in the region were trying to determine whether it was a third nuclear test. The USGS upgraded the magnitude of the possibly nuclear tremor from 4.9 to 5.1, located {{convert|24|km|mi}} east-northeast of [[Sungjibaegam]], North Korea.<ref name="USGS report summary">{{cite web|title=M5.1 – 24km ENE of Sungjibaegam, North Korea|date=12 February 2013 |url=http://earthquake.usgs.gov/earthquakes/eventpage/usc000f5t0#summary|publisher=USGS|accessdate=12 February 2013}}</ref> The tremor occurred at 11:57am [[Korea Standard Time|KST]] (2:57am [[UTC]]), and the USGS said the [[hypocenter]] of the event was only one [[kilometer]] deep.
Later, the [[Geophysical Service of the Russian Academy of Sciences|Geophysical Service]] of the [[Russian Academy of Sciences]] assures the residents in the [[Russian Far East]] that the nuclear blast did not trigger any seismic events and underground tremors at 16:00 local time on 12 February 2013 in the area and thus the North Korea's nuclear test does not pose danger to the residents there.<ref name="siberiantimes.com"/>
The [[China Earthquake Networks Center]] ([[Abbreviation]]: CENC; {{zh|s=中国地震台网中心}}) also reported this event, putting the magnitude at [[:Surface wave magnitude|M<sub>s</sub>]] 4.9.<ref name="朝鲜疑爆Ms4.9地震"/> The tremor caused by the test could be felt by residents of the neighboring city of [[Hunchun]] and [[Antu County|Antu]], in [[Yanbian Korean Autonomous Prefecture|Yanbian]], [[Jilin|Jilin Province]], China.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.ifeng.com/world/special/chaoxiansanheshi/content-3/detail_2013_02/12/22122280_0.shtml|title=吉林珲春市民感到晃动 老太错以为心脏病犯了_资讯频道_凤凰网|publisher=IFENG|date=12 February 2013|accessdate=12 February 2013}}</ref> A citizen of [[Hyesan]], [[Ryanggang Province]] of North Korea, {{convert|80|km|mi|abbr=on}} west from the nuclear test site, reported that many 5- and 7-floor buildings shook very severely, and this caused cracking.<ref>{{cite web|title= Hyesan Suffers Test Quake Damage |date=13 February 2013 |url= http://www.dailynk.com/english/read.php?cataId=nk01500&num=10314 |publisher=Daily NK|accessdate=14 February 2013}}</ref> The explosion was registered by 94 seismic stations and two infrasound stations in the CTBTO's global monitoring system.<ref>{{cite news|title=Update on CTBTO findings related to the announced nuclear test by North Korea |url=http://www.ctbto.org/press-centre/highlights/2013/update-on-ctbto-findings-related-to-the-announced-nuclear-test-by-north-korea/ |publisher=CTBTO|date=15 February 2013|accessdate=14 April 2015}}</ref> The CTBTO radionuclide network later made a significant detection of radioactive noble gases that could be attributed to the nuclear test.<ref>{{cite news|title=CTBTO detects radioactivity consistent with 12 February announced North Korean nuclear test |url=http://www.ctbto.org/press-centre/press-releases/2013/ctbto-detects-radioactivity-consistent-with-12-february-announced-north-korean-nuclear-test/ |publisher=CTBTO|date=23 April 2013|accessdate=14 April 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Gases "consistent with" North Korea's February test found: nuclear body |url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2013/04/23/us-korea-north-nuclear-idUSBRE93M0B820130423 |publisher=Reuters|date=23 April 2013|accessdate=14 April 2015}}</ref>
== Yield estimates == [[South Korea]]'s defense ministry said the event reading indicated a blast of 6–7 [[TNT equivalent|kilotons]],<ref name="USGS report summary"/><ref>{{cite web |first1=Gloria|last1=Riviera|first2=Fujita|last2=Akiko|title=North Korea Tremor Arouses Suspicion of Nuclear Test |url=http://abcnews.go.com/International/north-korea-tremor-arouses-suspicion-nuclear-test/story?id=18444191|publisher=ABC News|date=12 February 2013|accessdate=12 February 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|first1=David|last1=Chance|first2=Jack|last2=Kim|title=China joins U.S., Japan in condemning North Korea nuclear test |url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2013/02/12/us-korea-north-idUSBRE91B04820130212|agency=Reuters|accessdate=12 February 2013|date=12 February 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|first=Calum|last=MacLeod|title=Obama calls North Korea nuclear test a threat to U.S. |url=http://www.usatoday.com/story/news/world/2013/02/11/earthquake-north-korea-nuclear-test/1911587/|newspaper=USA Today|date=12 February 2013|accessdate=12 February 2013}}</ref> later revised to 6–9 kilotons using the Comprehensive Nuclear Test Ban Treaty Organization's calculation method.<ref name="KoreaHearldFeb14">{{cite news|url=http://www.koreaherald.com/view.php?ud=20130214000765|title=Estimates differ on size of N.K. blast|author=Choi He-suk|publisher=The Korea Herald|date=14 February 2013|accessdate=17 February 2013}}</ref>
The Korea Institute of Geosciences and Mineral Resources estimated the yield as 7.7–7.8 kilotons while the Japanese put the estimation between 8 and 10 kilotons.<ref name=chosun/>
Some experts estimate the yield to be up to 15 kilotons, since the test site's geology is not well understood.<ref>{{cite news |title=North Korea nuclear test raises uranium concerns |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-21431599|date=12 February 2013|accessdate=12 February 2013|work=BBC News}}</ref> The [[Ministry of Defence (Russia)|Russian Defence Ministry]] said the power of North Korea's nuclear test blast "surpassed 7 kilotons".<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.interfax.ru/world/290002|title=Пхеньян устроил "безупречный" взрыв|agency=[[Interfax]]|accessdate=14 March 2014|date=12 February 2013}}</ref><ref name="siberiantimes.com"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://indrus.in/world/2013/02/13/russia_condemns_north_koreas_new_nuclear_test_22253.html|title=Russia condemns North Korea's new nuclear test|first=Igor|last=Rozin|date=13 February 2013|publisher=|accessdate=23 October 2016}}</ref>
[[NORSAR]] compared the seismic data from all three North Korean nuclear tests and estimated the yield of the 2013 test as approximately 10 kilotons.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.norsar.no/norsar/about-us/News/NuclearExplosionDPRK12Feb2013|title=Nuclear explosion in North Korea, February 12, 2013|publisher=[[NORSAR]]|date=12 February 2013|accessdate=13 February 2013}}</ref>
The [[Bundesanstalt für Geowissenschaften und Rohstoffe|Federal Institute for Geosciences and Natural Resources]], a state-run geology research institute in [[Germany]], estimated the yield initially at 40 kilotons.<ref name="KoreaHearldFeb14"/><ref name="Nuke test air samples are a bust">{{cite web|title=Nuke test air samples are a bust |url=http://koreajoongangdaily.joinsmsn.com/news/article/article.aspx?aid=2967164 |date=15 February 2013 |accessdate=16 February 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130523095337/http://koreajoongangdaily.joinsmsn.com/news/article/article.aspx?aid=2967164 |archivedate=23 May 2013 |df=dmy }}</ref><ref name=BGR2013/> However, this estimation has since been revised to {{convert|14|ktonTNT|TJ}}<ref name=BGRJan2016/> after the [[January 2016 North Korean nuclear test]] was conducted.
On 19 June 2013, the [[University of Science and Technology of China]] released a report that claimed that they had found the precise location of the test at latitude 41°17′26.88″, longitude 129°4′34.68″, with an error margin of 94 meters and the yield at around 12.2 kt, with a margin of error of 3.8 kt.<ref name=UTSC/>
In comparison, the fission nuclear bombs dropped by the ''[[Enola Gay]]'' on Hiroshima ([[Little Boy]], a "gun-type" nuclear bomb) and on Nagasaki by ''[[Bockscar]]'' ([[Fat Man]], an "implosion-type" nuclear bomb) had blast yield equivalences of 16 and 21 kilotons respectively.<ref name="KoreaHearldFeb14"/>
== Further tests == On 4 February 2013, a South Korean military official had stated that there was a "chance that the southern tunnel is a decoy, but we are not ruling out that the regime will conduct nuclear tests simultaneously at both tunnels".<ref>{{cite news|last=Ryall |first=Julian |url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/asia/northkorea/9846447/North-Korea-preparing-for-two-nuclear-tests.html |title=North Korea 'preparing for two nuclear tests' |publisher=Telegraph |date=2013-02-04 |accessdate=2013-04-16 |location=London}}</ref> On 15 February 2013, North Korea had told China that they were preparing for one or two more nuclear tests this year.<ref>{{cite news|last=Kang |first=Benjamin |url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2013/02/15/us-korea-north-nuclear-idUSBRE91E0J820130215 |title=Exclusive: North Korea tells China of preparations for fresh nuclear test - source |publisher=Reuters |date=2013-02-15 |accessdate=2013-04-16}}</ref> On 8 April 2013, South Korea had observed activity at [[Punggye-ri Nuclear Test Site|Punggye-ri]], suggesting that a fourth underground test was being prepared.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://koreajoongangdaily.joinsmsn.com/news/article/article.aspx?aid=2969782&cloc=joongangdaily%7chome%7ctop |title=Activity at North's nuke test site-INSIDE Korea JoongAng Daily |publisher=Koreajoongangdaily.joinsmsn.com |date=2013-04-08 |accessdate=2013-04-16}}</ref> It was later believed that the tunneling activity that started in April was for a long-term project, and that a nuclear test wouldn't occur soon.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://38north.org/2013/06/punggye062413/|title=New Tunneling Activity at the North Korean Nuclear Test Site|author=38 North|publisher=38 North|date=25 June 2013|accessdate=26 June 2013}}</ref>
According to a U.S. expert, North Korea has everything in place for a fourth explosion but is hesitating due to the fear that it would anger China.<ref>{{Cite news|url = http://www.nbcnews.com/id/52497384/ns/world_news-asia_pacific/#.UeiTI2TwJYA|title = North Korea has everything in place for new atom test: U.S. expert|publisher = NBC News|last = Dahl|first = Fredrik|editor-first = Tom|editor-last = Pfeiffer|date = 17 July 2013|accessdate = 18 July 2013}}</ref> A professor from [[Georgetown University]] predicted that test would occur in spring 2014 at latest.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.globalpost.com/dispatch/news/yonhap-news-agency/131113/n-korea-could-conduct-4th-nuclear-test-late-year-us-expert|title=N. Korea could conduct 4th nuclear test late this year: US expert|publisher=''[[GlobalPost]]''|author=Yonhap News Agency|date=13 November 2013|accessdate=16 November 2013}}</ref>
On 17 December 2013, a member of South Korea's parliamentary intelligence committee said that a nuclear and missile test would occur soon to draw attention away from the execution of [[Jang Sung-taek]]. This was said after North Korea floated propaganda leaflets to South Korea that threatened the annihilation of [[Baengnyeongdo]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://world.time.com/2013/12/17/south-korean-official-the-north-is-preparing-for-another-nuclear-test/|publisher=TIME|title=South Korean Official: The North is Preparing for Another Nuclear Test|author=David Stout|date=17 December 2013|accessdate=17 December 2013}}</ref>
On 22 April 2014, South Korea reported that North Korea had stepped up its activity at its main nuclear test site, meaning they may be preparing for their fourth underground nuclear test.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.cnn.com/2014/04/21/world/asia/north-korea-nuclear-activity/|title=North Korea steps up activity at its nuclear site, South says|publisher=CNN|author1=Jethro Mullen|author2=Stella Kim|date=22 April 2014|accessdate=22 April 2014}}</ref> The United States urged North Korea to refrain from testing.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.reuters.com/article/us-nuclear-korea-usa-idUSBREA3L1FO20140422|title=U.S. urges North Korea to refrain from new nuclear test|author=|date=22 April 2017|publisher=|accessdate=23 October 2016|via=Reuters}}</ref>
On [[January 2016 North Korean nuclear test|January 6th, 2016]] North Korea says it has successfully carried out a [[hydrogen bomb]] test, which if confirmed, will be a first for the reclusive regime and a significant advancement for its military ambitions.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cnn.com/2016/01/05/asia/north-korea-seismic-event/index.html|title=North Korea says it has conducted hydrogen bomb test|first=Euan McKirdy|last=CNN|date=|publisher=|accessdate=23 October 2016}}</ref> The test took place at 10 a.m. local time, the regime said in a televised statement. The seismic event, which measured the event at a magnitude of 5.1, occurred 19 kilometers (12 miles) east-northeast of Sungjibaegam, the United States Geological Survey said. <ref>{{cite web|url=http://earthquake.usgs.gov/earthquakes/eventpage/us10004bnm?utm_source=dlvr.it&utm_medium=facebook#general_summary|title=M 5.1 Nuclear Explosion - 21km ENE of Sungjibaegam, North Korea|author=|date=|publisher=|accessdate=23 October 2016}}</ref> A senior U.S. administration told CNN it could take days to obtain the scientific data to determine whether this was a successful test.
== Reactions == {{main|International reactions to the 2013 North Korean nuclear test}} In response, Japan's Prime Minister, [[Shinzo Abe]], called an urgent security meeting of the [[United Nations Security Council]]. The emergency session was to be held 9 AM EST on 12 February 2013.<ref>{{cite news|title=Quake triggers doubts about North Korean nuclear test|url=http://www.rediff.com/news/slide-show/slide-show-1-seismic-activity-fuels-north-korean-nuclear-test-doubts/20130212.htm#1|newspaper=Rediff News|accessdate=12 February 2013}}</ref> [[United Nations Institute for Disarmament Research|Tibor Toth]], executive secretary of the [[Comprehensive Nuclear-Test-Ban Treaty Organization Preparatory Commission]] (CTBTO), confirmed the event's location was "roughly congruent with" nuclear tests carried out by North Korea in 2006 and 2009.<ref>{{cite web|title=N.Korea seismic event shows 'explosion-like characteristics' -CTBTO|url=http://www.trust.org/alertnet/news/nkorea-seismic-event-shows-explosion-like-characteristics--ctbto/|publisher=Trust.org|accessdate=12 February 2013}}</ref> Japan's [[Kyodo News]] service reported the Japanese defense ministry had scrambled aircraft to hunt for radiation effects.<ref>{{cite web|title='Artificial Earthquake' Suggests North Korea Just Tested a Nuclear Bomb|url=http://www.theatlanticwire.com/global/2013/02/north-korea-nuclear-test/62029/|publisher=Atlantic Wire|accessdate=12 February 2013}}</ref> Japan's government held a national security council meeting in [[Tokyo]] according to [[NHK]].<ref>{{cite news |first=Linda |last=Seig |title=Japan holding security meeting after N.Korea nuclear test report: NHK |url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2013/02/12/us-korea-north-japan-idUSBRE91B04T20130212 |newspaper=Reuters |date=11 February 2013 |accessdate=12 February 2013}}</ref> The South Korean military also raised its readiness level.<ref>{{cite news |author=Song Sang-ho |url=http://nwww.koreaherald.com/view.php?ud=20130212000692|title=N.K. has conducted 3rd nuke test |publisher=The Korea Herald |date=12 February 2013 |accessdate=12 February 2013}}</ref> In general, international reactions to the 2013 North Korean nuclear test have been almost uniformly negative.<ref>{{cite news|last=Chance |first=David |url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2013/02/12/us-korea-north-idUSBRE91B04820130212 |title=North Korean nuclear test draws anger, including from China |publisher=Reuters.com |date=2012-02-13 |accessdate=2013-02-13}}</ref>
